summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Obama Travels To Fire Up Young Voters
summary: Obama traveled to Madison, Wis., hoping to re-ignite the youth vote he won in 2008 for the benefit of Democrats in next month's mid-term elections.

headline: Yankees Finally Clinch
summary: By defeating the Toronto Blue Jays 6-1 at Rogers Centre, the Yankees locked up their 15th playoff berth in 16 years, quelling the mild hysteria caused by their recent poor play.

headline: Bill Gates and Warren Buffett visit China
summary: The three-and-half-day visit of Bill Gates and Warren Buffett to China this week has triggered an unprecedented public discussion about philanthropy among the country's new class of ultrarich.

headline: Higher Inflow Taxes Possible for Brazil
summary: Brazil's central bank president said that imposing higher taxes on flows into the South American country remains a possibility to stem the appreciation of the local currency.

headline: Wrongful Prosecution Suit Against City Is Dismissed
summary: Oliver Jovanovic, a former Columbia University doctoral student, can't pursue a malicious prosecution lawsuit against New York City after charges were dismissed against him in an alleged 1996 rape of a Barnard College student, a federal judge has ruled.

headline: Midtown Restaurant Settles Dispute Over Pay
summary: Nino's Positano Ristorante Italiano on Second Avenue in midtown Manhattan has agreed to pay $515,000 in back pay and damages to end a probe into alleged wage and hour violations, New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo said Tuesday.

headline: Thailand Approves State Firm's 3G Plan
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved a state-owned company's plan to invest roughly $650 million in a third-generation mobile-phone network.

headline: Accord Clears Way for City Payroll System
summary: New York City's long-delayed computerized timekeeping and payroll system is slated to be completed next year without any more payments coming from the city.

headline: China Encourages Public Housing
summary: China has introduced a series of tax exemptions for companies responsible for building and managing public rental-housing projects.

headline: Egypt Mogul's Death Sentence Commuted
summary: An Egyptian court handed a billionaire charged with killing his pop-star lover a lighter sentence of just 15 years after an earlier trial sentenced him to death.

headline: A Win for GOME's Small Holders
summary: GOME's shareholders have disappointed connoisseurs of boardroom dramas—but done themselves a big favor.

headline: Meaningful or Meaningless?
summary: Yankees Hope Their Dreadful September Doesn't Portend an Early Playoff Exit

headline: Big Hedge-Fund Firm Cutting 150 Jobs
summary: D.E. Shaw & Co. is cutting about 10% of its work force, among the largest cutbacks in recent memory among major hedge-fund firms, after losing more than half of its hedge-fund assets since the financial crisis.

headline: India Court to Allow Holy Site Verdict
summary: India's Supreme Court cleared the way for a verdict to be issued in a controversial case over whether Hindus or Muslims have rights to a disputed site in Uttar Pradesh.

summary: Bob DuPuy is stepping down from his post as president and chief operating officer of Major League Baseball.

summary: The second phase of the Mall of America is slated to begin in December. The owner envisions adding 5.6 million square feet to the 4.2 million-square-foot shopping mecca.

headline: Irish Government Faces Test
summary: Amid mounting challenges in the banking system, the economy and bond markets, Ireland's government faces a struggle for its own survival when parliament reconvenes after a 12-week break.

headline: Oil-Spill Panel Pushes for Subpoena Power
summary: The co-chairmen of a presidentially appointed panel probing the BP oil spill said a lack of subpoena power is hindering their ability to fully investigate the causes of and response to the disaster.

headline: Milan's Runways Predict a Bright Spring
summary: The spring collections shown at Milan this week were awash in brilliant colors, bold, clashing patterns and canny designs that managed to be at once wearable and fashionable, says fashion columnist Christina Binkley. Here are some highlights from the runways of Milan fashion week.

headline: Private-Equity Dreams
summary: None

headline: Bets on Fed Aid Help Stocks
summary: The Dow rose 46.10 points as investors saw weak economic data as a sign the Fed may be more likely to introduce more stimulus.

summary: Republicans on the House ethics committee said Democrats were stalling the trials of Democratic Reps. Rangel and Waters and called for hearings to begin ahead of the Nov. 2 elections.

headline: North Korea Confers New Titles on Heir Apparent
summary: North Korea's ruling Workers Party added new titles to the duties of Kim Jong Il's heir apparent, Kim Jong Eun, a day after he was named a four-star general, establishing him in the country's two centers of power, the military and the party.

summary: The major broadcast networks and Major League Baseball have sued Ivi Inc. for providing streaming live television for a fee via its Web site without their authorization.

summary: Chinese quick-service chain Country Style Cooking Restaurant Chain dished up the third-best IPO of the year, with its shares gaining nearly 50%.

headline: Oppenheimer Currency Fund Aims to Get Ahead of Inflation
summary: Oppenheimer Currency Opportunities Fund aims to protect investors from the near-certain time when import-price inflation returns.

summary: Crude futures fell 34 cents to $76.18 a barrel as conflicting economic data kept oil firmly in its recent trading range.

summary: Copper has surged more than 30% from June's lows, lifted by improving industrial demand and concerns about global supply.

summary: An appeals court told a lower court to take another look at the royalty rates it set for Yahoo and RealNetworks to pay to the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

summary: Tire maker Michelin launched a heavily discounted $1.6 billion capital increase to finance its expansion, particularly in fast-growing emerging markets.

summary: Asian stock markets fell Tuesday, with Chinese banks and property firms skidding on concerns that Beijing may initiate more measures to cool property prices. Most European indexes edged down.

summary: Chief Justice John Roberts recently sold his stock holdings in Pfizer, which clears him to participate in two cases involving the drug maker that are pending on the Supreme Court's docket.

summary: The FDA warned Johnson & Johnson, CVS Caremark and Walgreen to stop marketing mouth-rinse products with claims that they reduce plaque above the gum line or promote healthy gums.

summary: This landmarked Morris Township, N.J., estate dates to the late 1800s. Since then, the home has undergone two major renovations, the latest of which sought to restore the home's original French details.

summary: Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi met his key allies ahead of a major test on whether he still has a majority in parliament.

summary: Once a Wall Street consensus gathers around a perceived policy stance, the horses have already bolted. That can be very problematic for the Fed.

summary: Japanese government bond yields fell, as bond buying got support from increasing expectations for additional easing by the Bank of Japan and sharp gains in U.S. Treasurys overnight.

summary: Takefuji, which Tuesday filed for bankruptcy, was the last of Japan's major consumer lenders to remain both solvent and independent.

summary: Toyota, Nissan and Honda Motor revved up domestic production in August, just before the government's consumer incentives ended.

summary: The president's trip may not accomplish very much of note.

summary: "The New York Earth Room," a curious art installation that has endured in SoHo since 1977, has always consisted of exactly one piece: 280,000 pounds of dirt.

summary: Wal-Mart offered to buy South Africa's Massmart for $4.6 billion, making a foray into the fast-growing African market.

summary: Thirty-seven years after he last conducted the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Riccardo Muti finally began his tenure last week as the ensemble's music director.

summary: British DJ and producer Mark Ronson discusses his latest album, "Record Collection," for which he brought in more than a dozen collaborators, including D'Angelo, Q-Tip, Boy George, and Simon Le Bon and Nick Rhodes of Duran Duran.

summary: Southwest Airlines agreed to acquire AirTran for $1.4 billion in cash and stock, the first major merger between U.S. discount carriers.

summary: The financial-services industry is built for speed. But while superlow interest rates are meant to be high-octane fuel for the economy, they are gumming up financial engines.

summary: Manchester City takes another step down the path from loss-making rich man's plaything to soccer power.

summary: November's election is likely to bring a dozen or so new Republican governors to power, introducing fresh GOP faces into positions where they can influence politics for years.

summary: The EU and the U.S. are increasingly at odds over the future of regulations governing airline ownership, and it is the EU that is pushing to loosen rules while a key congressman is pushing to tighten them.

summary: Ed Miliband's victory signals a return to an agenda the party had supposedly left behind.

summary: The emirate that shook up global markets when it halted payments on its corporate flagship's bonds late last year is gearing up to sell new bonds, underscoring improving sentiment for the city-state.

headline: Gome Vote Leaves Battles Ahead
summary: GOME shareholders rejected founder Huang Guangyu's resolution to oust the company's chairman, though the imprisoned businessman blocked an effort to dilute his stake.

summary: A bitter confrontation with Beijing following an East China Sea ship collision is energizing Japan's conservative politicians and right-wing activists.

summary: A luxurious duplex apartment on London's Chelsea Harbor offers panoramic views of the capital's skyline over the River Thames.

summary: Ralph Gardner Jr. hangs out with Robert Forbes—son of the legendary publisher of Forbes magazine, hot-air-balloon enthusiast, childhood bagpiper and nursery rhyme book writer.

summary: Details have emerged in a recall of Johnson & Johnson's Tylenol products that are drawing new scrutiny to the company's handling of quality problems involving its popular over-the-counter medicines.

summary: Chávez suffered a political blow in congressional elections, losing the ability to pass new laws at will after opposition candidates banded together behind unified candidates.

summary: Unilever said it has reached an agreement to purchase Alberto Culver, maker of Alberto VO5 hair-care products, for $3.7 billion.

summary: The Jets defeated the Miami Dolphins, 31-23, in a pressure-packed game before 70,481.

headline: Ruling Limits Claims of Fraud
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court has given multinational companies a powerful new legal defense against fraud claims made by some of their investors.

headline: Mudslides Hit Southern Mexico

headline: No Budget, but California Is All Over the Cow Issue
summary: In California, a budget was due three months ago, and the legislature hasn't passed one. Lawmakers have, however, voted to create a lobster commission, a "Cuss Free Week" and lined up support for the "Happy Cows" bill.

headline: TransDigm to Acquire McKechnie Aerospace

summary: Vivendi sold off part of its stake in NBC Universal, as expected, under Comcast's plan to control the media company. Meanwhile, NBCU said it would sell more debt to help finance Comcast's deal.

headline: ObamaCare's Hotel California
summary: The state moves to impose price controls you can never leave.

headline: Lender Reflects Japan's Struggles
summary: Takefuji plans to file for bankruptcy protection with the Tokyo District Court, as reports say tighter regulations have hit its finances.

headline: The Graph Shows More If Upside Down
summary: Regarding "The Cost of Washington" graph of federal spending as a percentage of GDP ("Principles for Economic Revival" by George Shultz et al., op-ed, Sept. 16): It may be helpful to turn the graph upside down, to show the dwindling share of GDP that remains private.

summary: India's Reliance Capital is evaluating options to enter the banking sector and list its life insurance unit as the company seeks to expand its financial services business in the world's second-fastest-growing major economy.

summary: Plaintiffs' attorneys jostling to secure lead roles in federal litigation against BP over the Gulf oil spill are showing a bit of swagger in court filings, hoping a judge will pick them for key posts.

summary: Fed officials are considering new tactics if they resume purchases of long-term U.S. Treasury securities. They are weighing a more open-ended, smaller-scale program that they could adjust as the recovery unfolds.

summary: Iraq's Shiite Muslim political leaders ended a special conclave without reaching consensus on a candidate for prime minister, the latest setback in a marathon to form a new government.

summary: Scientists clashed over whether oil from the BP spill remains in the Gulf and is breaking down quickly, in a sign of the challenges facing a presidential commission investigating the spill.

summary: Buying AirTran Holdings should certainly benefit Southwest Airlines. It is the rest of the industry that should be worried.

summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAILAnother re-election roadblock for Obama.

summary: Key parts of the Obama administration's technology agenda are stalled, but FCC Chairman Genachowski said he's impatient to move them forward soon.

summary: Thieves have been snatching more gadgets from the hands of subway riders, police said. There were 118 grand larcenies in the New York City subway system in August, 14.6% more than in the same month a year ago.

summary: Wal-Mart is just one of several global companies targeting South Africa for expansion opportunities this year.

summary: China Telecom will "closely examine" opportunities for overseas acquisitions and is in talks with three Indian telecom carriers to establish a cable connection between China and India, an executive said.

summary: This triplex in a former church in Brookline, Mass., features half of an original stained-glass rosette window. It also has two bedrooms, two-and-a-half bathrooms and a loft.

headline: The Send Jobs Overseas Act
summary: Ending the deferral of foreign income is another tax on U.S. employment.

headline: Belgian Auction Eases Concerns

headline: Kathleen Sebelius: Health Insurers Finally Get Some Oversight
